overview: VS Code 1.102 highlights major Copilot Chat and MCP milestones: the Copilot Chat extension is open sourced, MCP support is generally available, and MCP server discovery/installation and management UX are significantly expanded. The release also improves customization workflows (modes/prompts/instructions), introduces experimental terminal auto-approval, and adds new ways to inspect and debug chat interactions.

detailed_explanation.title: Copilot Chat open source milestone
bullets: Announces the GitHub Copilot Chat extension source is available at microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat under the MIT license.
The notes describe this as enabling community contributions and transparency for chat modes, custom instructions, and MCP integration implementation.

detailed_explanation.title: Chat customization improvements
bullets: Improves custom chat modes, including support for specifying which language model to use via metadata.
Adds better editor support for modes/prompts/instructions files (completions, validation, hovers for metadata).
Introduces mechanisms to load instruction files on demand when relevant instructions aren’t already attached.

detailed_explanation.title: Terminal auto approval (experimental)
bullets: Introduces an experimental mechanism to auto-approve certain terminal commands based on allow/deny lists.
Explains handling of chained and inline commands and provides example allow/deny patterns.
States the allow list is empty by default and discusses possible future defaults.

detailed_explanation.title: MCP becomes generally available
bullets: States MCP support is now generally available in VS Code.
Adds support for MCP server discovery and installation via curated lists and VS Code UX entry points.
Introduces an MCP Servers management view for starting/stopping/restarting, viewing logs, config, model access, and resources.

detailed_explanation.title: MCP servers as first-class resources
bullets: Describes MCP servers being stored in a dedicated profile-specific mcp.json rather than user settings.
Notes Settings Sync integration and profile separation for MCP server configuration.
Describes migration support from settings.json-based MCP configurations, including in remote/WSL/Codespaces scenarios.

detailed_explanation.title: Agent workflow and diagnostics
bullets: Adds agent awareness of tasks and terminals, including a tool to read task output to avoid duplicate runs.
Adds a debug view to inspect the full details of chat requests and tool calls, with an explicit warning that logs may contain personal information.

detailed_explanation.title: MCP ecosystem integration
bullets: Adds support for MCP elicitations (server-requested user input) per the latest MCP specification.
Improves MCP install/management UX, including editor views with readme/manifest/runtime configuration.

key_changes: Copilot Chat extension is open sourced (MIT).
MCP support is generally available and expanded with discovery, installation, and management experiences.
MCP servers move to profile-specific mcp.json as first-class resources with migration support.
Custom chat modes gain model selection metadata and improved authoring support.
Instruction files can be loaded on demand for large conditional rule sets.
Experimental terminal auto approval via allow/deny lists.
Chat debugging tools to inspect prompts, enabled tools, responses, and tool calls.
impact: Teams adopting MCP can more easily discover, install, and manage servers and keep configurations profile-scoped and synced.
Developers and extension authors can inspect and contribute to Copilot Chat’s implementation due to the open source release.
Users building standardized AI workflows benefit from improved mode/prompt/instructions authoring support and conditional instruction loading.
Power users and maintainers get stronger diagnostics via request inspection tooling (with privacy considerations).
caveats: Terminal auto approval is described as experimental; security risks and future UX improvements are discussed but exact timelines are not stated in the article.
MCP elicitations support depends on the latest MCP specification; further evolution of the specification is not detailed in the article.
The chat debug log may contain sensitive information; the release notes explicitly warn users to review logs before sharing.
insights: The release positions MCP as a mainstream extension surface, not a niche feature, by investing in discovery, management, and migration.
Open sourcing Copilot Chat reinforces a strategy of transparency and community collaboration around AI editor tooling.
There’s an emphasis on making AI workflows auditable and debuggable (chat debug view) alongside adding more autonomy (auto-approval experiments).
